author: bergmeister
body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
Test-Path ' '
```

Expected behavior
-----------------
NB: Because the .Net Core method Directory.Exists states in the docs [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.io.directory.exists?view=netcore-2.0#System_IO_Directory_Exists_System_String_) that trailing whitespaces are removed, the expectation of the last 2 spaces is true.
```none
False
```

Actual behavior
---------------
On Windows:
```none
True
```
On Linux (Ubuntu 17 or WSL):
```none
False
```

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body:
In case anyone wonders how I discovered this:
I was debugging someone else's script today whereby one parameter was expected to be an invalid file path, hence I just used a space but found that not everything was working locally as expected, which I could boil down to an if statement making the wrong decision because of this.

comments.body: You could use the notation `'[ ]'` or `\\?\c:\` if you want leading or trailing spaces in paths and file names.

comments.author: KevinMarquette
comments.body:
This is hitting on a weird nuance of DOS Path processing. Any number and combination of trailing spaces and periods can be added to the end of a file or path name and it will be ignored.

    Test-Path '...   ...   ...   ...'
    Get-ChildItem '...   ...   ...   ...'

This is the best guide that I have seen on all the DOS Path and NT Path parsing nuances: [The Definitive Guide on Win32 to NT Path Conversion](https://googleprojectzero.blogspot.com/2016/02/the-definitive-guide-on-win32-to-nt.html)

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body:
Although this issue was originally due to unintuitive legacy behaviour, the behaviour is now worse in 6.1 with .Net Core 2.1 where results are now inconsistent
````powershell
Test-Path ' '
True
[System.IO.Directory]::Exists(' ')
False
[System.IO.File]::Exists(' ')
False
````
